elements.name: csp_or_csd
elements.title: [HIDDEN FIELD] For which course are you completing this survey?

elements.name: clickTo57
elements.html:
Welcome to the 2019-20 {csp_or_csd} post-course survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool through which we remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about our curriculum and your teaching experience.

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share anonymous, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your anonymized responses will be used by Code.org, our Regional Partners, and our facilitators for program improvement.

This survey should take less than 15 minutes to complete.

At the end you will be offered at $10 Amazon gift code for your time.

Your honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: clickTo190
elements.html:
Professional Development

We're interested in knowing the types and characteristics of professional development activities you engage in.  

When considering these items, please think about professional development for computer science or computer science teaching you participated in as a teacher.  Please don't include courses you took or education prior to becoming a teacher, or time you spent providing professional development for others.

elements.name: when_last_pd
elements.title: When did you most recently participate in professional development focused on computer science or computer science teaching?

elements.name: clickTo175
elements.html: >> SHOW IF PD WITHIN LAST 3 YEARS <<

elements.name: type_of_last_pd
elements.title: Within the last 3 years, which types of professional development related to computer science or computer science teaching have you had? (check all that apply)
choices: I participated in Code.org's professional development program.
I attended another (non-Code.org) professional development program/workshop.
I attended a national, state, or regional computer science teacher association meeting.
I participated in a professional learning community/lesson study/teacher study group.
I received assistance or feedback from a formally designated coach/mentor.
I took a formal course for college credit.

elements.name: reasons_for_no_PD
elements.title: If you DID NOT attend an in-person professional development program within the last 3 years, what were the strongest reasons why? (choose up to 2)
choices: N/A I did attend an in-person professional development program
Felt I didn't need it to teach the course successfully
Felt it wouldn't be worth the time/cost
Unaware of professional development programs in my area (or not available)

elements.name: time_doing_pd
elements.title: What is the TOTAL amount of time you have spent on professional development related to computer science or computer science teaching in the last 3 years? (reference: a typical 5-day summer workshop is about 35 hours of PD)

elements.name: pd_activities
elements.title: Considering all of your computer science-related professional development in the last 3 years, to what extent do the following describe your experiences? Complete the phrase: I had opportunities to...

rows.text: Deepen my own computer science content knowledge, including programming.
Experience lessons, as my students would, from the units I use in my classroom.
Examine classroom artifacts (for example: student work samples, e-portfolios, videos of classroom instruction).
Rehearse instructional practices during the professional development (meaning: try out, receive feedback, and reflect on those practices).
Apply what I learned to my classroom and then come back and talk about it as part of the professional development.

elements.name: Show
elements.html: >> END  SHOW IF PD WITHIN LAST 3 YEARS <<

elements.name: preparedness_heading
elements.html:
Preparedness and Skills

{csp_or_csd} entails a number of skills that represent the intersection of content knowledge and particular practices.

One way to self-assess your current skills is to think about "how true" it is that you could do certain things along a scale from "Not true of me now" to "Very true of me now".  You can also think about it in terms of your own development and preparation for teaching.  Please consider this response scale for the items that follow.

N/A   1----2 3----4----5 6----7
    Not true of me now
need more development,
not well prepared

 Somewhat true of me now
in process developing, somewhat prepared
 Very true of me now
current strengths,
well prepared
respond N/A if you think the skill is unnecessary or irrelevant for teaching computer science.

elements.name: csp_skills
elements.title: Please rate the degree to which you can do the following things by completing the phrase: Right now I can...

rows.value: Use a structured problem solving process to iteratively improve a project.
rows.text: Use a structured problem solving process to iteratively improve a project.

rows.value: Develop a program for creative expression, to satisfy personal curiosity, or to create new knowledge.
rows.text: Develop a program for creative expression, to satisfy personal curiosity, or to create new knowledge.

rows.value: Make responsible decisions as both a creator and consumer of public content, considering the needs and rights of others.
rows.text: Make responsible decisions as both a creator and consumer of public content, considering the needs and rights of others.

rows.value: Explain the differences between how humans and computers approach problems.
rows.text: Explain the differences between how humans and computers approach problems.

rows.value: Explain the beneficial and harmful effects of computing.
rows.text: Explain the beneficial and harmful effects of computing.

elements.name: codeorg_strategies_descriptive
elements.title: In teaching {csp_or_csd}, right now, I have teaching strategies or techniques that I use to...

rows.text: Ensure that students work collaboratively when writing code.
Create a classroom culture in which students regularly get feedback on their work from their peers.
Ensure that every student has a daily opportunity to share ideas and be heard by classmates through partnered conversations, small-group or large-group discussion.
Create a culture in which problems or failures are normalized and welcomed as a natural part of the problem solving process.
Provide frequent opportunities for students to do reflective writing as a way to promote sense-making and self-expression.

elements.title: In thinking about teaching {csp_or_csd} again next year, I am concerned about...

rows.text: My own computer science content knowledge.
Code.org course materials.
Systemic supports (district, school, principal, community, parents, etc.).
Other CS content supports (extra resources, materials, assessments, videos, online community, colleagues, online forums, etc.).
The amount of time needed to cover all the material.
Managing and understanding the variety of technology I need to teach the course.
My class being fully enrolled (or recruiting students into the class)

elements.name: clickTo151
elements.html:
You and Your Computer Science Classroom


The following items ask how often you did certain things interacting with students while teaching {csp_or_csd}. 

Please answer as candidly as possible so as not to inflate or deflate the amount you do these things.

Again, your responses are confidential and not used to evaluate you or your teaching. We are interested in capturing an accurate picture of Code.org CS classrooms across the country.

elements.name: teacher_facilitation_of_risk
elements.title: While teaching {csp_or_csd} this year, how often did YOU explicitly do the following?

rows.text: Encouraged students to answer questions even if they were not sure they were correct.
Encouraged students to take risks and try new things even if they might make mistakes.
Encouraged students to share ideas if they were different from others.

elements.name: facilitation_cog_demanding_work
elements.title: While teaching {csp_or_csd}, how often did you explicitly ASK STUDENTS to do the following?

rows.text: Consider alternative approaches to their work.
Explain the logic and reasoning supporting their solutions.
Explain why they agree or disagree with the work of other students.

elements.name: clickTo91
elements.html:
Teaching Philosophy

Below are pairs of statements from computer science teachers describing various teaching philosophies, presented as Statement A and Statement B like so:  

Statement A        Statement B
...   ...

 

  1 2 3 4 5  
Strongly aligned with A  ◉ ◉ ◉ ◉ ◉ Strongly aligned with B
     Leaning towards A   Neutral / Can't Decide   Leaning towards B    

Please select the value 1-5 that best shows how closely your own beliefs are to one of the statements in a given pair. Please respond freely based on your personal beliefs and philosophy - there is no wrong way to respond.

elements.name: leadLearner_statements
elements.html:
Statement A        Statement B
"I do not need to have deep expertise in computer science in order to successfully teach it. I have expertise in how to learn, and I can model that for my students as we learn the content together."   "As the teacher I need to have deep content expertise so that I can properly answer students’ questions and guide instruction appropriately."

elements.name: abccbv_statements
elements.html:
Statement A        Statement B
"For computer science instruction I think it’s important to present students with appropriate terms and vocabulary before they explore a concept or problem in more depth. That way we’re all 'speaking the same language’ from the outset."   "I like to present students with a computer science problem, or with tools that let them explore a concept before teaching the terms and vocabulary. I think that sometimes the terminology gets in the way of exploring the ideas."

elements.name: recruitResponsibility_statements
elements.html:
Statement A        Statement B
Computer science teachers’ responsibility is to promote their computer science classes broadly, to all students. The diversity of the class will reflect those most interested in taking a computer science class.   Computer science teachers have a responsibility to recruit a set of students into their classrooms that are representative of the school’s population in terms of diversity (gender, racial, socio-economic, etc.)

elements.name: prioritizeTime_statements
elements.html:
Statement A        Statement B
It’s important that the teacher prioritize their time and resources for students who have the most need.   The teacher should ensure that their time, and students’ access to resources are distributed equally for all.

elements.name: instructionFocus_statements
elements.html:
Statement A        Statement B
Instruction and class activities should focus on maintaining high standards and rigor so that students reach the highest level of achievement, even if some students struggle with the material.   Instruction and class activities should focus on ensuring that students with the least prior knowledge and preparation are not left behind, even if that means that less material can be covered.

elements.name: question7
elements.html:
Teacher at-home survey

Teaching Code.org at Home How can Code.org help you instruct students while they are at home? Please fill out this quick (5 minutes or less) survey to let us know how we can better serve you while your students are at home. Thank you in advance for your answers and for all that you do for your students!

elements.name: question6
elements.title: Which most accurately describes your current teaching situation?

choices.text: I'm currently providing remote/distance/virtual instruction for my classes.
I'm not yet providing remote/distance/virtual instruction for my classes, but I expect to in the near future.
I or my school are not currently planning to provide remote/distance/virtual instruction for any classes.

elements.name: question8
elements.title: How are you instructing your students while they are at home?

rows.text: SYNCHRONOUS virtual meetings (Zoom, Skype, Hangouts, etc.)
ASYNCHRONOUS (work assigned/distributed via email, learning platform, etc.)
Non-virtual / non-technology (i.e. students receive printed packets, no/low tech)
I hold "office hours" (students can contact me at set times through approved channels).

elements.name: question9
elements.title: To the best of your knowledge, what types of devices are your students using (or have access to) for doing school work at home right now?

rows.text: Phone
Tablet
Chromebook
Laptop/Desktop
No device available

elements.name: question10
elements.title: To the best of your knowledge, approximately what percent of students have adequate internet access at home that they can use for school work?

elements.name: question11
elements.title: Which Code.org course(s) are you teaching now (or were you teaching prior to your school moving to remote/distance learning)? Check all that apply.	(checkbox)

elements.name: question12
elements.title: Which of the following best describes your plans to teach with Code.org materials while students are at home?

choices.text: I am no longer teaching Code.org or using Code.org materials.
I would like to continue teaching with Code.org materials but I probably cannot because it doesn’t convert well to my remote learning situation.
I'm using Code.org but not the same materials or lessons I was using before.
I'm planning to continue teaching my Code.org course with major modifications due to remote/at-home learning.
I'm planning to continue using Code.org materials pretty much the same as I was before.

Providing feedback on work students have done
Assigning new work
Finding materials that students can work on independently
Getting students their login information
Finding materials to work on that don't require internet and device access
Communicating with my students while they are at home
Providing instruction on new concepts to my students
Finding ways for students to collaborate
